message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oral diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to manage atrial fibrillation. Its adverse effects include hypotension, bradycardia, and peripheral edema. Among the options, only bilateral pedal edema is a potential side effect of diltiazem. Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are not associated with this medication, and multifocal atrial tachycardia is a different cardiac arrhythmia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and can cause edema, particularly in the lower extremities. Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are not common side effects of diltiazem. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a cardiac arrhythmia and not a side effect of diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina, and it can cause peripheral edema. Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are not common side effects of diltiazem. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a separate condition that is not related to the use of diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and can cause peripheral edema as a side effect. Bloody diarrhea is not a known side effect of diltiazem, nor is Stevens-Johnson syndrome or multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are not side effects of diltiazem. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is not a side effect, but rather a different type of arrhythmia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, the most common side effect of diltiazem is bilateral pedal edema, so the physician should warn the patient about this possibility. Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are not common side effects of diltiazem. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a different condition than atrial fibrillation and would not be a side effect of diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Oral diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that can cause peripheral edema, especially in the lower extremities. Bloody diarrhea is not a known side effect of diltiazem, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare and severe adverse reaction to medication that typically presents with skin lesions. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a separate cardiac arrhythmia that is not related to diltiazem treatment. Therefore, the physician should warn the patient about the possibility of bilateral pedal edema as a common side effect of the medication.

One of its common side effects is bilateral pedal edema, which the physician should warn the patient about. Bloody diarrhea is not a known side effect. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe and rare skin condition associated with certain drugs, but not with diltiazem. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a different condition from atrial fibrillation and is not related to the use of diltiazem.

Bloody diarrhea and Stevens-Johnson syndrome are rare side effects. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is not a side effect of diltiazem, but rather a different arrhythmia.
